concept.title: The Day Scrapz Gave a Shit
concept.core_premise: Scrapz discovers something that forces him to care despite his cynical nature
concept.merchandising_hook: Character transformation that breaks his established identity
concept.target_audience: Cynics who secretly have hearts, people who relate to emotional walls

story_catalyst.event: Scrapz finds an injured kitten that reminds him of his younger self
story_catalyst.internal_conflict: Caring vs. cynicism, vulnerability vs. protection
story_catalyst.external_threat: Urban redevelopment threatens to destroy the kitten's home
story_catalyst.stakes: First time Scrapz has cared about anything in years

character_arc.act_1: Scrapz reluctantly helps kitten, denies caring
character_arc.act_2: Grows attached despite himself, starts taking risks
character_arc.act_3: Must choose between safety and fighting for what matters
character_arc.transformation: From "I don't give a shit" to "I give a shit about THIS"

t_shirts: The Day Scrapz Gave a Shit
I Don't Give a Shit... But Scrapz Does
From Zero Shits to One Shit Given
stickers: Scrapz giving middle finger with heart

scrapz_main_arc.title: Episode 1: The Unwanted Discovery
scrapz_main_arc.plot_outline: Scrapz faces a typical day that goes from bad to worse when misunderstanding escalates absurdly. What starts as a simple attempt to pay overdue rent becomes a meditation on even cynics can't ignore suffering as Scrapz encounters the usual cast of neighborhood characters and discovers that even small victories come with a price.

scenes.title: Rock Bottom Has a Basement
scenes.action: Scrapz begins their day with the usual routine of avoiding responsibility and managing expectations. The catalyst for today's adventure presents itself in the form of an overdue bill. Despite every instinct screaming "don't get involved," circumstances and poor judgment combine to draw Scrapz into the situation.

dialogue.speaker: Madame Zelda
dialogue.line: Why do I always get involved in these situations?
dialogue.tone: weary sarcasm
dialogue.subtext: testing whether this person can be trusted

dialogue.line: Why does this always happen?

scenes.title: When Bad Gets Worse
scenes.action: The situation escalates when their addiction/vice creates a new problem. What seemed like a manageable problem reveals itself to be connected to larger issues involving medical malpractice. Scrapz realizes they're in deeper than anticipated and that their usual strategy of "ignore it and hope it goes away" won't work this time.

dialogue.speaker: Rizzo
dialogue.line: Let me guess, someone needs the expert on suffering.
dialogue.tone: dark humor as a defense mechanism against trauma
dialogue.subtext: terrified of being vulnerable again

dialogue.line: Everyone's got an angle, what's yours?
dialogue.tone: sharp cynicism barely masking deeper hurt

scenes.title: Same Shit, Different Day
scenes.action: The episode concludes with Scrapz having learned nothing from their experience but somehow finding themselves in a slightly different variation of the same situation they started in. Victory is redefined as "not making things significantly worse," and the audience is reminded that some problems don't get solvedâ€”they just get replaced with new problems.

scrapz_main_arc.title: Episode 2: Accidental Attachment
scrapz_main_arc.theme: The walls we build protect us from caring
scrapz_main_arc.plot_outline: Scrapz faces a typical day that goes from bad to worse when temptation proves irresistible. What starts as a simple attempt to avoid eviction becomes a meditation on the walls we build protect us from caring as Scrapz encounters the usual cast of neighborhood characters and discovers that even small victories come with a price.

scenes.title: Rock Bottom Has a Basement
scenes.action: Scrapz begins their day with the usual routine of avoiding responsibility and managing expectations. The catalyst for today's adventure presents itself in the form of an unexpected encounter with someone from their past. Despite every instinct screaming "don't get involved," circumstances and poor judgment combine to draw Scrapz into the situation.

supporting_episodes.title: Rizzo Understands Pain
supporting_episodes.theme: Everyone has something they care about
supporting_episodes.plot_outline: Rizzo's carefully constructed solitude is disrupted when they're forced to interact with a social worker with good intentions. As secret revealed at worst time, both characters must confront their issues with trust, intimacy, and the fact that everyone has something they care about.

scenes.title: Rock Bottom Has a Basement
scenes.action: Rizzo begins their day with the usual routine of avoiding responsibility and managing expectations. The catalyst for today's adventure presents itself in the form of a minor emergency that requires leaving their comfort zone. Despite every instinct screaming "don't get involved," circumstances and poor judgment combine to draw Rizzo into the situation.

dialogue.speaker: Rizzo
dialogue.line: Death would be preferable to whatever you're about to ask.
dialogue.tone: dark humor as a defense mechanism against trauma
dialogue.subtext: testing whether this person can be trusted

finale.plot_outline: Scrapz faces a typical day that goes from bad to worse when misunderstanding escalates absurdly. What starts as a simple attempt to return library books becomes a meditation on community forms around caring as Scrapz encounters the usual cast of neighborhood characters and discovers that even small victories come with a price.
